In the other Elands River tributaries (Ngodwana, Gladdespruit, Stadspruit and Houtbosloop) forestry related practices with high road network densities and stream crossings resulted in excessive sedimentation and the loss of habitat availability to this species, resulting in the disappearance of this species in most of these streams. Large forestry fires in 2010 furthermore attributed to sedimentation of instream fish habitats. In the upper Mlumati River, Swaziland, similar conditions relating to unregulated forestry threatens this species.
population: This mainstem species is naturally found at relatively low population densities and based on comprehensive population studies by Kleynhans (1984) its historic relative abundance in relation to other fish species sampled from appropriate habitat was 2.8% and catch per unit effort (CPUE) was 0.18 fish/minute electrofishing. O’Brien et al. (2014) assessed the different CPUE trends dating back to 1989 (Kleynhans 1992, James 1992) and also conducted seven fish surveys from March 2002 to August 2006. The CPUE rates during these surveys the for Incomati Suckermouth ranged between 0.04 and 1.73 fish/minute electrofishing, In 2013 the Mpumalanga Tourism and Parks Authority (MTPA) conducted a comprehensive study on the Ecostatus of the Crocodile River Catchment during which 56 biomonitoring sites were sampled (Roux and Selepe 2013). Chiloglanis bifurcus were only sampled from three of the 56 sampling sites, two in the Elands River and one in the Crocodile River, close to its confluence with the Elands River. In conjunction with a small number of sites from which this fish was sampled, the CPUE 0.06 fish/minute electrofishing was indicative of a drastic decline in the population. Particularly relevant was that no Incomati Suckermouth were recorded at the type locality in the Crocodile River downstream of the 50 m high Kwena Dam (formerly Braam Raubenheimer Dam). It would appear that stream regulation from the dam has had a detrimental effect on the downstream population of this species. During this study the species was also not recorded in the Houtbosloop tributary as intensive forest fires in 2010 resulted in excessive siltation and sedimentation altering and reducing its available habitat.In September 2013 and April 2014 high flow and low flow surveys were conducted to determine stream flow conditions in the Elands River relating to the impact of the Sappi Paper Mill at Ngodwana (Diedericks and Roux 2014). During the low flow period survey no Incomati Suckermouth were sampled despite the collection of 477 individuals of other fish species during an electrofishing sampling effort of 97 minutes. During the high flow period surveys only four adults were recorded, resulting in a CPUE of 0.04 fish/minute electrofishing and a relative contribution to the fish community of 1.23%. Thus for both the high and low flow surveys the average combined CPUE value was 0.02 and a population density of 0.49%. In comparison to the historical CPUE of 0.18 fish/minute electrofishing the 2013/14 survey indicated a decline in the population density of Incomati Suckermouth (Kleynhans 1986). In 2016 an intensive study was conducted to determine the overall status of the Incomati Suckermouth population across its extent of occurrence. In the Ngodwana River, described as a sanctuary area (James 1992), three adult individuals were collected from two sites that were surveyed with a combined sampling effort of 138 minutes resulting in a CPUE value of 0.02 individuals/minute electrofishing (relative abundance= 0.24%). This observed reduction can possibly be related to the presence of the invasive alien species such as Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss). For the other seven biomonitoring sites on the Elands River and tributaries only ten adults were sampled with a CPUE value of 0.03 (relative abundance = 0.36%). These recent surveys indicate that the population in the Elands River catchment and tributaries has suffered a >90% reduction in distribution and a decline in AOO as well as a loss of habitat quality. Further, the subpopulation in the Crocodile River reach below the Kwena Dam is likely to be extinct and the population recorded in the Ngodwana River is now fragmented and threatened by alien fishes. For the subpopulation recorded in the Upper Mlumati River, Swaziland, very little information is available. However, due to unregulated forestry activities, most of these streams in Swaziland are severely sedimented and it is suspected that this subpopulation is also at risk.
range: This species has a restricted distribution and is endemic to the Inkomati River System and within this system it is restricted to altitudes between 900 m.a.s.l to 1200 m.a.s.l. It historically occurred in the Crocodile and Elands River and in some of its sub-tributaries (Elands, Ngodwana, Gladdespruit and Stadspruit) (Kleynhans 1984). Recently only sampled from a small section of the Elands River and Crocodile River as well as in a few tributaries of the Mlumati River in South Africa and Swaziland.
conservationActions: The distribution range of Incomati Suckermouth is entirely within privately owned land without any formal conservation protection. The two remaining subpopulations need to be given priority for conservation efforts. Land and water use practices need to be carefully managed and stocking of alien organisms need to be stopped. The most effective way might be through conservancy agreements with riparian land owners and the Mpumalanga Parks Board. The Elands River and its tributaries have been identified as priority freshwater environments for fish conservation and are listed as a fish sanctuary in the National Freshwater Ecosystem Priority Areas (NFEPA) (Driver et al. 2011).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable (VU) because, despite being abundant in some locations and having tolerance for some human disturbances, it has an extent of occurrence of 6,978 km<sup>2</sup>, and it occurs in less than ten threat-defined locations in Cordillera de La Costa, where forests are rapidly being degraded.
habitat: This species is arboreal and nocturnal, and occurs on vegetation along streams in montane forest. It tolerates some degree of habitat modification. Males call from leaves, shrubs and even on moss on stones on the banks of stream, up to about 3 m high above the water. Eggs clutches of 7 to 20 eggs are laid on the underside or upside of leaves, moss or branches that, when developed, fall into the water where they complete their development. This species does not present parental care. The advertisement calls in captivity are described by Señaris and Ayarzagüena (2005), and in nature by Wen et al. (2012).
threats: The major threats for this species are deforestation for urban and infrastructure development, agriculture (commercial, and for subsistence), logging, and pollution. The forest vegetation in the central part of the Cordillera de La Costa (≥1,000 m asl), where this species inhabits, has been classified as Vulnerable (Rodríguez et al. 2010). Currently, the forest ecosystems inside protected areas in the upper elevations of this mountain system are relatively well preserved, but outside, urban and infrastructure development, agriculture, logging, pollution and the recreational activities along the streams continue to increase. In the mountain system in Carabobo state, gold mining along the rivers and streams is a recent and increasing illegal activity, that threatens amphibian communities in this portion of the Cordillera de La Costa (Señaris obs. pers. 2017-2018). Additionally, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis is present in Cordillera de La Costa and some amphibian species have experienced local chytrid-related extinctions (e.g., Atelopus cruciger).
population: This species is seasonally very common, at least in some localities of its geographical distribution. Castillo (2012) estimated a relative abundance of 27.55 adult individuals/100m2 in La Guáquira stream at 153 m asl (Yaracuy state). In 2018, dozens of reproductive adults, pairs in amplexus and clutch of eggs were observed during the wet season in several forested streams, some with secondary vegetation or anthropogenic disturbance, in Altos de Canoabo (Carabobo state) (J.C. Señaris pers. obs., April-August 2018).
range: This species is known from primary and secondary forests on the northern slope and central regions of the Cordillera de la Costa (Aragua and Carabobo states), Cerro Azul (Cojedes state), and the Serranía del Interior (Yaracuy state), northern Venezuela, between almost sea level up to 1,300 m asl (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2005, Lotzkat 2007, Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018, Señaris et al. 2019).
useTrade: This taxon does not have any known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are no conservation measures specifically for this species but its range overlaps with several national parks: Henri Pittier, Miguel José Sanz in San Esteban National Park and General Manuel Manrique in Tirgua.

Conservation Needed
Effective forest and stream preservation, and continued management, at least in the existing protected areas, are essential for the conservation of this species. Illegal mining activities in Cordillera de la Costa must be stopped, especially within or in the vicinity of national parks.

Research Needed
Further research into the population status and threats of this species is needed.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened (NT) because, despite having an extent of occurrence under 20,000 km2, in a geographic area where the extent and quality of its habitats are declining, this species occurs in many threat-defined locations (at least twelve), it is abundant in some them and it has some tolerance for habitat degradation. This species may need uplisting to a threatened category, if habitats, particularly streams and their surrounding gallery forests, continue to be degraded in Cordillera de La Costa.
habitat: It is an arboreal, nocturnal species frequently found in the gallery forests along permanent or seasonal streams in montane forests. It tolerates some degree of habitat modification. Males call from the underside of leaves, between 1 to 3 m high above the water. Eggs clutches of 20-25 eggs are laid on the underside of leaves, and tadpoles fall into the water where they complete their development. This species has parental care. The advertisement call is described by Wen et al. (2012).
threats: The main threats to this species are deforestation and habitat fragmentation, due to the growth of urban areas and the expansion of agricultural activities (commercial, and subsistence) and the associated pollution leaching to water reservoirs. Also, the abstraction of surface water from streams for domestic or commercial use is an increasing concern. The forest vegetation in the central portion of the Cordillera de La Costa, where this species inhabits, has been classified as Endangered or Critically Endangered (up to 100 m asl) and Vulnerable (between 600 and 1,000 m asl) (Rodríguez et al. 2010). Although forests within the limits of protected areas in the upper elevations of this mountain system are relatively pristine, lowland ecosystems, particularly those associated with rivers and streams, are threatened by urban developments and recreational activities. In the mountain chain in Carabobo state, gold mining along the rivers and streams is a recent but rapidly increasing illegal activity, that threatens amphibian communities, especially riparian, in this portion of the Cordillera de La Costa (Señaris obs. pers. 2017-2018). Additionally, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis is present in Cordillera de La Costa and some amphibians’ species have experienced local chytrid-related extinctions (e.g., Atelopus cruciger).
population: This species is very common in some localities such as Sierra de Aroa in Yaracuy state, and in the mountains in Carabobo state. In 2018, dozens of reproductive adults, pairs in amplexus and clutch of eggs were observed during the rainy season in several forested streams in Altos of Canoabo (Carabobo state) and in slow-flowing streams surrounded by highly degraded secondary forests (J.C. Señaris pers. obs., April-August 2018).
range: This species is known from primary and secondary forests on the northern slope and central regions of the Cordillera de la Costa (Aragua, Carabobo and Vargas states), in Sierra de Aroa and Macizo de Nirgua (Yaracuy state), and the mountains system in the northern Cojedes state, Venezuela, between 100 to 1,400 m asl (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2005, Lotzkat 2007, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018, Señaris et al. 2019).
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are no conservation measures specifically for this species. Its range overlaps with Henri Pittier National Park, San Esteban Nacional Park, Tirgua National Park, and Yurubí National Park.

Conservation Needed
Effective forest and stream preservation, and continued management at least in the existing protected areas are essential for the conservation of this species. Illegal mining activities in Cordillera de la Costa must be stopped, especially inside or close to the national parks.

Research Needed
Further research into this species' geographic distribution, ecology, population trends and threats is needed. Also, its habitat must be monitored in light of the increasing levels of human activities in the area.

rationale: Listed as Endangered (EN) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is only 4,975 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from only three threat-defined locations in Cordillera de La Costa, where the extent and quality of its forest habitat is declining, as well as its area of occupancy, number of locations and number of mature individuals.
habitat: The species occurs on vegetation overhanging and adjacent to mountain streams, in forests. Males were found at night, calling both on the upper side and underside of leaves, at heights between 1 and 5 metres above the stream. Females deposit ca 20-26 eggs on the upper sides of leaves, and males takes care of the egg clutches, until the larvae fall into the streams, where they complete their development. Advertisement calls and tadpoles are described by Señaris and Ayarzagüena (2005).
threats: The main threats to this species are deforestation and habitat fragmentation, due to the growth of urban areas and the expansion of agricultural activities (commercial, and subsistence) and the associated pollution leaching to water reservoirs. The forest vegetation in the central portion of the Cordillera de La Costa, where this species inhabits, has been classified as Endangered or Critically Endangered (up to 100 m asl) and Vulnerable (between 600 and 1,000 m asl) (Rodríguez et al. 2010). Within the limits of Waraira Repano National Park, forests are relatively well protected in the upper portions of the mountain, but in lower elevations the annual fires, the infrastructure development (telecommunication services, and abstraction of surface water for commercial and subsistence use), and recreational activities are increasing threats. Specifically, in Chacaíto river within the park limits, pollutants from recreational activities and religious rituals (“Santeria”) that use streams to build altars, bonfires, and sacrifice domestic animals (JL Vieira, pers obser 2014), appears to be an important threat. Additionally, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis is present in this area and some sympatric amphibians have experienced local chytrid-related extinctions (e.g., Atelopus cruciger).
population: The species was described from five adult males: the holotype collected in 1997, and four paratypes obtained in 1938 (one individual), 1939 (three individuals), and 1970 (one individual). Between 1997-1998, the type locality was surveyed nine times but no other individuals were sighted or heard besides the holotype. In November 2014, a reproductive population with abundant calling males, gravid females, eggs clutches, and tadpoles, was found in the upper basin of the Chacaíto River in the Waraira Repano (El Ávila) National Park. There have been no more sightings of this species, despite intensive explorations of Cordillera de La Costa. Based on the low number of sightings and specimens deposited in museums, this species appears to be rare and probably declining.
range: This species is known from the central part of the Cordillera de La Costa, in northern Venezuela, at altitudes between 720 and 1,200 m asl (Señaris et al. 2018, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). The historical records of “Cochranella fleishmanni” from Colonia Tovar (Aragua state) and Cotiza River (Distrito Capital) referred by Rivero (1961) probably corresponded to this species; if so, this species should have an altitude distribution up to 1,900 m asl, but currently these localities are widely degraded by anthropogenic activities.
useTrade: This taxon does not have any known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are no conservation measures specifically for this species but its range overlaps with Waraira Repano (El Ávila) National Park, and Macarao National Park. This species is also listed as EN in the most recent Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Señaris et al. 2018, http://wikieva.org.ve/index.php/Hyalinobatrachium_guairarepanensis).

Conservation Needed
Effective forest and stream preservation, fire control, and continued management of existing protected areas are required for the conservation of this species. Environmental vigilance in the Waraira Repano (El Ávila) National Park must be reinforced in order to stop the illicit activities inside the park, and preserve the Chacaíto river basin,. An extensive local educational program is also needed.

Research Needed
Further research into this species' geographic distribution, ecology, population trends and threats is needed. Also, its habitat must be monitored in light of the increasing levels of human activities in the area. The presence of Bd in the remnant population of this species and in amphibian communities of the Chacaíto river needs to be determined.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because, despite being a poorly known species, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is only 475 km2, and it is known from only two locations, where there is a continuing decline in the quality of gallery cloud forests and water sources.
habitat: Almost nothing is known of the natural history of this species. It is a riparian frog that inhabits along narrow mountain creeks surrounded by cloud forests and sub-paramo shrublands (La Marca 1993, La Marca and Manzanilla 2004). Like many other aromobatids, this species is likely to make terrestrial nests near creeks, where males care for tadpoles and carry them on their backs to small pools to complete their development.
threats: The major threat to this species is habitat degradation and loss due to small-scale agriculture (including crops and livestock), and associated use of agrochemicals, abstraction of surface water for irrigation, and human-caused forest fires (La Marca and Manzanilla 2004, Manzanilla et al. 2007, Señaris and Rojas-Runjaic 2015). Spontaneous fires have also increased in the last decade in some lowland areas of this mountain system where Colocasia esculenta timber plantations were established (D. Flores pers. obs.). The construction of roads for telecommunication installations at the top of some mountains near Elvecia (Manzanilla et al. 2007) constitutes an additional threat, since these serve as vectors for the establishment of new human settlements and cultivation areas. Señaris and Rojas-Runjaic (2015) pointed out that chytridiomycosis is a potential threat to this species, but the occurrence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis in amphibian communities in the region is still pending evaluation.
population: It is known only from the two specimens of the type series collected in 1932 at Mount Turimiquire (Schmidt 1932), and an additional lot of 24 specimens collected in 1930 at Elvecia (Rivero 1984), a second location about 30 km WSW of the type locality. The high number of specimens from Elvecia suggests that the species was common at that locality (Señaris and Rojas-Runjaic 2015). It is suspected that the absence of additional specimens in biological  collections and of recent records in the field may be a consequence of  the lack of surveys for this species.
range: This species is only known from two localities between ca 1,700-2,630 m asl (Mount Turimiquire and Elvecia) on the southern slopes of the Turimiquire massif, in the eastern part of the Venezuelan Cordillera de la Costa (Schmidt 1932, Rivero 1984, La Marca 1993). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 475 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Its range is entirely included in the Macizo de Turmiquire Protective Zone of Rivers. This species is listed as Endangered (EN) in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Señaris and Rojas-Runjaic 2015).

Conservation Needed
Because Protective Zone of Rivers is not a strict conservation area, strengthening surveillance and effective environmental control related to watershed and forest protection would contribute to the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Because this species was last seen almost a century ago, exhaustive fieldwork to several localities in the Turimiquire massif is necessary to rediscover the species. Studies based on historical DNA obtained from its type series, would help to elucidate its phylogenetic position in the absence of recently collected specimens. This would also allow searching for this missing species using environmental DNA detection techniques. Also, because its ecology and habitat requirements are not known, research is required on its geographic distribution, natural history, population size and trends. The presence of the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis in Peninsula de Paria needs to be confirmed and the species vulnerability to the disease assessed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in light of the continuing uncertainties about its extent of occurrence, number of locations or subpopulations, threats and population status.
habitat: This is a diurnal and terrestrial species of tropical rainforest. Specimens were found in a muddy roadside ditch with shallow water in tropical montane forests at Sierra de Lema (Meinhardt and Parmelee, 1996). Specimens were collected by day at the edge of Río Danto and a small stream. Larvae of this species develop in shallow (5–10 cm deep) water of slow-moving streams, as well as in small streams and under rocks in small pools.
threats: This species is currently threatened by tourism and deforestation for the construction of power lines and access roads to the Gran Sabana. Ditches, where this species were previously found, are now paved (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). Also, at La Escalera, its only known locality, streams have been polluted and forests have been degraded by gold mining operations (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).
population: This species was previously reported to be a common species. However, it is now thought to be extinct at its type locality (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). It was last seen in 1993 (by K. Jungfer), but multiple surveys in 2000, 2009 and 2010 by different researchers have failed to record it since then (Fouquet et al. 2015, P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).
range: This species is known from the type locality, from km 112 in El Dorado-Santa Elena de Uairen Road in Bolívar state, Venezuela (Meinhardt and Parmelee 1996) at 860 m asl. It may also occur at La Escalera Region, Sierra de Lema, and its distribution probably extends through the Gran Sabana Region (Duellman 1997) and El Paují, also in Bolívar state (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019), but the taxonomic identity of these specimens need to be confirmed before being included in the extent of occurrence. It is also likely to occur in adjacent Guyana, however, there are no records from this country so far.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade for this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are no conservation actions in-place specifically aimed at this species, but the extension of its known presence is contained entirely within the limits of the Canaima National Park.

Research Needed
There is significant uncertainty regards this species' distribution, population size and potential threats. The taxonomic status of specimens from El Pauji and Kavanayen need to be confirmed as these would increase its extent of occurrence significantly. Also further surveys at and around its type locality are required to confirm its disappearance and identify causes or potential threats.

rationale: It is listed as Least Concern since it occurs mostly in pristine areas of extensive suitable habitat, which do not appear to be under significant threat, and it has a presumed large population. Protected areas management, national law enforcement, and research are recommended.
habitat: This arboreal and nocturnal species inhabits stream-side pristine lowland and montane tropical forest, where it is found on branches or leaves. Males call from arboreal bromeliads and trees (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017), close to streams, between 2.5 and 4 m above the ground (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2011). Eggs and tadpoles are unknown. There is no information available on its breeding habits, though reproduction is likely to take place in streams.
threats: There are no known threats to this species, and most of the known localities are located in undisturbed, remote areas. In the La Escalera region of Venezuela, the habitat of this taxon is partially threatened by tourism and deforestation for the construction of power lines and access roads to the Gran Sabana, and also by illegal gold mining operations in some areas. In Guyana, an ongoing increase of mostly unregulated tourism on Mount Roraima (Kok et al. 2013), and gold mining in Mount Ayanganna and around the base of Wokomung massif could be impacting the habitat of this species. No research has been recently carried out in Wokomung massif, where it is unknown whether the subpopulation has increased and spread up into the higher elevations (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).
population: The population size is unknown. It appears to be relatively abundant in the Guyana localities, and rare and less abundant in Venezuela. The population trend is presumed to be stable since it lives in pristine forests.
range: This species is known from the forested slopes of Mount Roraima, Mount Ayanganna, and Wokomung in west-central Guyana, and several localities in La Escalera region (Sierra de Lema), and slopes and summit of the Auyán-tepui in Bolívar state, Venezuela (Duellman and Hoogmoed 1992, MacCulloch and Lathrop 2005, Barrio-Amorós and Duellman 2009, Señaris et al. 2009, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2011). It ranges between 490 and 1,600 m asl. Although it has not been reported from Brazil, its presence in northern Roraima State is expected (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2011). It is likely to occur more widely, but this requires confirmation.
useTrade: This taxon does not have any known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present in the protected area of Parque Nacional Canaima in Venezuela (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). There are no conservation measures specifically aimed at this taxon. 

Conservation Needed
Continuous management of protected areas is essential, and strengthening compliance with national laws related to forest protection would contribute to the conservation of this species. 

Research Needed
The biology and range limits are poorly known, hence research on distribution, ecology, life history, population status, and threats, and population monitoring, are required.

rationale: Listed as Endangered (EN) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,249 km2, it occurs in five or less threat-defined locations in the central portion of Cordillera de La Costa, where there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of forests habitats. This species disappeared has disappeared from its type locality and, it is possible that is extent of occurrence has decreased.
habitat: This arboreal species inhabits cloud montane forest, where there is continuous forest cover. Reproduction takes place in temporary or permanent ponds and slow-flowing streams within or at the edge of cloud forests. Males call at night, and perch on leaves or branches around ponds, between 30 and 200 cm above ground. Clutches with up to 72 eggs are placed on flat leaves, or in crevices of logs covered with moss. When eggs hatch, the larvae fall into the water to complete their development (Cannatella 1980, Hertz and Lotzkat 2010, Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2014). This species can live in secondary forests, and can even breed in artificial small ponds in heavily degraded areas, as long as there is dense tree cover (Señaris et al. 2019). The Braided Groundsnake Erythrolamprus zweifeli appears to be a common predator of egg masses of this species (Funkhouser 1962, Lotzkat 2007). The advertisement call of this species was described by Hertz and Lotzkat (2010).
threats: The main threats to this species are deforestation and habitat fragmentation, due to the growth of urban areas and the expansion of agricultural activities (commercial, and subsistence) as well as pollutants leaching to water reservoirs. Also, the abstraction of surface water from streams for domestic or commercial use is an increasing concern. The forest vegetation in the central portion of the Cordillera de La Costa, where this species occurs, has been classified as Endangered or Critically Endangered (up to 100 m asl) and Vulnerable (between 600 and 1,000 m asl) (Rodríguez et al. 2010). Although forests within the limits of protected areas in the upper elevations of this mountain system are relatively pristine, lowland ecosystems, particularly those associated with rivers and streams, are threatened by urban developments and recreational activities. In the mountain system in northern Carabobo state, fires and more recently illegal gold mining along the streams, are additional threats (C. Señaris pers. obs. 2017–2019). Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been detected in some of the localities where this leaf frog was been observed. At these localities, other amphibian species have experienced local chytrid-related extinctions (e.g., Atelopus cruciger).
population: This species appears to be rare (Barrio-Amorós 2009), or very difficult to detect. It is usually found in temporal or permanents pools in cloud forests, during the wet season. In the last decade new sightings in pristine forests of Yaracuy state suggested small but stable reproductive populations (Proy 2000, Hertz and Lotzkat 2010, Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2014). It has also been found in secondary forests, near artificial lagoons or pools in the mountain system north of the Carabobo state (C. Señaris pers. obs., Señaris et al. 2019). In its type locality in Rancho Grande, however, this species has not been sighted in the last decades (Barrio-Amorós 2009, Manzanilla and La Marca 2010). A drastic decline or local extinction of the subpopulation at its type locality is presumed.
range: This species is known from several localities, in the cloud forest of the central portion (Aragua, Carabobo and Yaracuy states) of the Cordillera de La Costa in Venezuela, between 975 and 1,447 m asl (Lotzkat et al. 2007, Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2014, Señaris et al. 2019).
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are no conservation measures specifically for this species, but its extent of occurrence includes Yurubí National Park and, formerly, Henri Pittier National Park.

Conservation Needed
Effective forest and stream preservation and management, at least in the existing protected areas, is essential for the conservation of this species. Illegal mining activities in Cordillera de la Costa, accidental fires and deforestation must been stopped immediately, especially within or in the vicinity of protected areas.

Research Needed
Phylogenetic analyses are needed to determine its evolutionary relationships with other species of its genus. Also, further research into the distribution, ecology, life history, population status and threats of this species is needed. The presence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis in the region needs to be urgently investigated, as well as the vulnerability of this species to chytridiomycosis. An assessment of the potential effects of habitat loss and fragmentation in the Paria mountain ecosystems is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in light of the continuing uncertainties about  its extent of occurrence, number of locations and subpopulations, threats  and population status.
habitat: An arboreal, nocturnal species that lives in lowland or montane forests including the surrounding ecotones. This species has been found in the vegetation around permanent or temporary water bodies including ponds and streams. Reproductive congregations have been observed. Males calls from leaves of herbaceous vegetation and bushes (Duellman 1986, 1997, Gorzula and Señaris 1999).
threats: Although this species' distribution overlaps with Canaima National Park (Señaris et al. 2014), tourism and deforestation for the construction of power lines and access roads to the Gran Sabana are ongoing threats. At La Escalera (Sierra de Lema, below 500 m), at the only known locality, streams have been polluted and some forests have been degraded by gold mining operations (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2011). In the upper basin of the Cuyuní river, 20 thousand miners were reported by 2005 (Farina et al. 2009).
population: This species has been collected four times, in 1974, 1975, 1981 and in 2009. It was common at the type locality in La Escalera, when 27 specimens were collected (Duellman 1986). In 1981 and 2009 a few specimens were also collected in lowlands and uplands near La Escalera, some within the limits of Canaima National Park (Gorzula and Señaris 1999, C.L. Barrio-Amorós pers. comm. to Gilson Rivas). The area in which it occurs is a remote and inaccessible area that is largely under-explored.
range: This species is only known from La Escalera, Sierra de Lema, in southeastern Bolívar state, Venezuela, between 110 and 1,250 m asl (Duellman 1986, Gorzula and Señaris 1999, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). The geographic distribution of this species is still largely unknown, but it could occur more widely, probably in Guyana (Barrio Amorós et al. 2019). Señaris and Rojas-Runjaic (2020) refer to this species as an element of the Central Guayana.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-place
There are no conservation actions in-place specifically aimed at this species, but the extension of its known presence overlaps with the Canaima National Park. This species is listed as Data Deficient (DD) in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Rodríguez et al. 2015).

Research Needed
There is significant uncertainty regards this species' distribution, population size and potential threats. Further surveys at and around its type locality are required to confirm its presence.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large and stable population, and because, although there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in parts of its range due to mining activities and pollution, it also occurs in an area of extensive, suitable, well-preserved habitat.
habitat: This is a nocturnal species usually found on marginal vegetation of rocky permanent streams, most frequently closely associated with cascading mountain streams, on clean boulders in, and at the edges of streams, perched perpendicular to some branches over streams, and in the spray zone of waterfalls. During the daytime, juveniles and adults can be found hiding under rocks or in the vegetation beside streams. Like other members of the genus, females carry up to 16 eggs on their backs, and juveniles fully develop on their mother's back (Gorzula et al. 1983, Señaris et al. 1997, Salerno and Pauly 2012). The advertisement call is described by Sinsch and Juraske (2006) (under the uncorrected name Stefania evansi).
threats: The subpopulation in Kamarang Falls in Guyana is not presently threatened, as the area is fairly pristine and remote (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). In the La Escalera region in Venezuela (the type locality), this species is currently threatened by tourism and deforestation for the construction of power lines and access roads to the Gran Sabana. Also, in this area, streams have been polluted and forests have been degraded by gold mining operations (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). This frog is also at threat in the Uey river, in the Cuyuní river basin in Venezuela, due to extensive legal (and probably also illegal) gold mining. In the rest of its range in Sierra de Lema and on the slopes of the Auyán-tepui, its subpopulations apparently don't have any direct threats.
population: In Guyana, it is a locally common species and the subpopulations are apparently stable (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2019). In Venezuela, it appears common and relatively abundant in the middle Uey River Basin (Señaris et al. 2009) in the La Escalera region (Duellman 1997, Gorzula and Señaris 1999, Barrio-Amorós and Duelmann 2009), northwest corner of Sierra de Lema (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2011), and also on the slopes of the Auyán-tepui (Señaris et al. 2004). Its subpopulations are apparently stable.
range: This taxon is present in Guyana and Venezuela. In Guyana, this species is only known with certainty from its type locality of Sierra de Lema in the La Escalera region, and in Kamarang Falls (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017), from 600-1,500 m asl. The previous records from Mount Ayanganna were a misidentification and are now thought to belong to an undescribed species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). In Venezuela, this species is known from the uplands of eastern Bolívar State (Gorzula and Señaris 1999, Señaris et al. 2004, Barrio-Amorós and Duellman 2009, Kok et al. 2017), and from Uey River in the Cuyuní River Basin (Señaris et al. 2009), at 130-1,360 m asl. It may occur more widely, and could possibly be found in Chivaton, Venezuela (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 30,366 km2.
useTrade: This taxon does not have any known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The Venezuelan subpopulations are protected within Canaima National Park in Bolívar State (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). There are no conservation measures specifically for this species. It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Rodríguez et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
Continued management of the protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species. Illegal mining in the area must be immediately stopped. An education program among tourists to make them aware of not handling amphibians in the wild is recommended.

Research Needed
Taxonomic research is required to verify the identity of the subpopulations at Mount Ayanganna in Guyana (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). Further research into population status and threats are needed (C. Señaris pers. comm. 2020).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, despite a continuing decline in the quality and extension of forest habitats of the northern mountain system, its estimated extent of occurrence is 49,176 km2 and it appears to be abundant in most of its range.
habitat: It is a terrestrial nocturnal species that lives in lowland humid and montane cloud forests. During the day, individuals hide in the forest litter; juveniles have been seen in a dry stream bed with high leaf litter humidity. This species breeds by direct development and buries its eggs in the ground, in the litter, or places them on mossy substrates (Barrio-Amorós and Kaiser 2008).
threats: The major threats for this species are deforestation for urban and infrastructure development, agriculture (commercial, and for subsistence), logging, and pollution. The forest vegetation in the central part of the Cordillera de La Costa (≥1,000 m asl), and Península de Paria where this species occurs, have been classified as Vulnerable (Rodríguez et al. 2010). The forest ecosystems inside protected areas in the upper elevations of this mountain system are relatively well preserved, but at lower altitudes, urban and infrastructure development, agriculture, logging, pollution and recreational activities along the streams continue to increase. In the mountains of northern Carabobo state, fires and recent illegal gold mining along the streams, represent additional threats for the amphibian communities (Señaris obs. pers. 2016–2018). Chytridiomycosis also constitutes a potential threat to this species, since some sympatric species in the Cordillera de la Costa tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Lampo et al. 2008, Nicolás 2007) and some of them have experienced population declines presumably linked to this fungal disease (e.g., Atelopus cruciger; Manzanilla and La Marca 2004b, Rodríguez-Contreras et al. 2008).
population: Its population size or trends have not been estimated. Nevertheless, despite being difficult to detect because it camouflages with the forest litter, it is frequently observed  throughout its range (Manzanilla and La Marca 2004a). Manzanilla et al. (1995) described it as one of the most common anurans in the cloud forest of Rancho Grande at Henri Pittier National Park. At Cerro Zapatero, in the Nirgua massif (western part of Cordillera de la Costa), it seems especially abundant above 900 m asl (Lotzkat 2007) In 2014, it was also common in a secondary evergreen montane forest in Sierra de Aroa (F. Rojas-Runjaic, pers. obs. 2014). Only in the mountain system of Carabobo state, this species appears to be rare (Señaris pers. obs. 2016–2018).
range: This species is widely distributed throughout the mountainous systems of northern Venezuela (Lara-Falcón system, western, central and eastern Cordillera de la Costa), between 150–1,380 m asl (Manzanilla et al. 1995, Barrio-Amorós 1999, Rivero and Mijares-Urrutia 2004, Lotzkat 2007, Barrio-Amorós and Kaiser 2008).
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
There are no conservation measures specifically aimed at this species, but it occurs in at least seven protected areas (Cueva de la Quebrada del Toro, Yurubí, San Esteban, Henri Pittier, Waraira Repano, Guatopo, and Península de Paria national parks). It is likely to be present in several other protected areas in northern Venezuela. This species is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Rodríguez et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
Effective cloud forest preservation, and continued management of the existing protected areas are essential for the conservation of this species. Illegal mining activities in Cordillera de la Costa, anthropogenic fires and deforestation must be stopped. Strengthening compliance with national laws on watershed and forest protection would also contribute to the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Research on the distribution, ecology, life history, population status and threats of this species is needed. Its vulnerability to chytridiomycosis needs to be assessed, given that the fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis is widespread in Cordillera de la Costa.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution presumed stable population, and because it does not appear to be under significant threat.
habitat: This diurnal species inhabits tropical rainforests, usually adjacent to streams. Tadpoles have been found in the La Escalera region amidst leaves in a slow-flowing, tannin-coloured stream on a sandy substrate (Duellman 1997). It also uses streams with rocky riverbeds. Males call from between rotten trunks, holes, mats of roots, and from under rocks, usually near swampy areas. The tadpoles burrow in the sandy bottom of streams.
threats: This species occurs in an area of limited human impact. However, it is probably affected by local threats such as tourism and deforestation for the construction of power lines and access roads to the Gran Sabana in La Escalera region, forest habitat degradation due to illegal gold mining in some areas of Sierra de Lema, and, at the type locality on the trail to the summit of Roraima-tepui, disturbance by tourists.
population: It is common within its range and has a stable population.
range: This species is present in Guyana and Venezuela. In Venezuela, it occurs in Sierra de Lema and the uplands of Gran Sabana (Auyán-tepui slopes, La Escalera, Roraima- tepui slopes, and Arabopó) in Bolívar State. In Guyana, it has been reported from Kurupung River, upper Potaro River, Meamu River, Kaieteur National Park, and the slopes of Mount Ayanganna, Mount Roraima, and Mount Wokomung. It ranges between 615 and 1,411 m asl. It might occur in adjacent Brazil, but this requires confirmation.
useTrade: This taxon does not have any use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is present in the protected area of Canaima National Park in Venezuela (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020).

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population status and natural history is also recommended.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is only 8,124 km2, it occurs in less than 10 threat defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. This species has disappeared from some localities where it was previously common.
habitat: It is a nocturnal, arboreal species. It occurs in semi-deciduous premontane moist and cloud forests, and evergreen forest of the Cordillera de la Costa and Sierra de Aroa in Venezuela (Manzanilla et al. 1995, Lotzkat 2007). Individuals of this species have been found on vegetation (particularly bromeliads) at night (Manzanilla et al. 1995). Lotzkat (2007) sighted a specimen apparently feeding on ants. It is a direct developing species.
threats:
The major threats for this species are deforestation for urban and infrastructure development, agriculture (commercial, and for subsistence), logging, and pollution (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010). Additionally, the mountain rivers and streams across Cordillera de la Costa are often use for recreational activities. The forest vegetation in the central part of the Cordillera de La Costa (≥1,000 m asl), where this species occurs, has been classified as Vulnerable (Rodríguez et al. 2010). Currently, the forest ecosystems inside protected areas in the upper elevations of this mountain system are relatively well preserved, but outside urban and infrastructure development, agriculture, logging, pollution and the recreational activities along the streams continue to increase.

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Venezuela.
population: This species is seldom seen and has rarely been collected in the last three decades. The three main zoological museums of Venezuela contain 21 specimens collected between 1969 and 2006 at locatities in Aragua and Yaracuy states. Most of the only 17 specimens located through a VertNet search (vertnet.org, Constable et al. 2010) on 16 September 2019 have been collected between 1940 and 1976 in the vicinity of the biological station Rancho Grande in Henri Pittier National Park, Aragua state, Venezuela; this species was apparently common at this locality. However, no individuals have been observed there in the last two decades, even though some surveys have been done (Barrio-Amorós 2006, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). The most recent observation (one specimen) was made by Lotzkat (2007) on the western slopes of Cerro Zapatero at the Estación Ecológica La Guáquira, Yaracuy state. There is no information on the current population size or population trends for this species.
range: This species was described by Trapido in 1942 using a single specimen collected in the vicinity of the Borburata River Valley in Carabobo state. It has now been observed at 11 localities along the central portion of the Cordillera de la Costa (Aragua and Carabobo, states), west to the Nirgua massif, and Sierra de Aroa, both in Yaracuy state, Venezuela (Trapido 1942, Manzanilla et al. 1995, Barrio-Amorós 1999, Lotzkat 2007, GBIF 2019). The documented localities range between 400-1,100 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is only 8,124 km2.
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
There are no conservation measures specifically aimed at this species but it is known to occur in three protected areas: Parque Nacional Henri Pittier (Aragua state), Parque Nacional San Esteban (Carabobo state), and Reserva Ecológica Privada La Guáquira (Yaracuy state).

Conservation Needed
It is necessary to enforce park boundaries and its land use restrictions.

Research Needed
Further research is needed to determine its population size and trends, threats and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence and area of occupancy, as currently known, are only 4 km2, it occurs in a single location when considering the threat of agriculture and telelecommunications infrastruture expansion, which could drive the species to Critically Endangered or Extinct in a very short period of time. If the species is found to have a larger range, it will need to be reassessed.
habitat: It is a nocturnal terrestrial species that lives in premontane and montane forests. It was observed in a pristine riverine forest near a small fast-water creek and in a patch of secondary forest within a matrix of primary forest on the top of a mountain (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010; Rojas-Runjaic and Infante-Rivero 2018). This forest had a 4 m canopy height with many arboreal ferns, vines and Cecropia plants. Calls were heard at the end of the dry season in March, during late afternoon and night, and, occasionally, during cloudy days; males called, hidden or exposed, from leaves and branches near the ground. As other terraranans, this species may also have direct development. Its high abundance in the secondary forest suggests some degree of tolerance to habitat disturbance. However, survival of this species on nearby American taro (Xanthosoma sagittifolium) plantations seem unlikely because the land is completely cleared (Rojas-Runjaic and Infante-Rivero 2018).
threats: Cerro Las Antenas, the only known locality for this species, is currently well protected due to the presence of radio communication antennas. However, because nearby lowland habitats are being rapidly deforested for agricultural purposes and this mountain is not included in the national system of protected areas, current protection status could change and this species could be threatened by agricultural activities or other activities associated with the expansion of the existing telecommunication infrastructure, in the near future (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010; IUCN SSC ASG 2012; Rojas-Runjaic and Señaris 2015; Rojas-Runjaic and Infante 2018).
population: This species appears to be abundant with a relatively non-fragmented population (Rojas-Runjaic and Infante-Rivero 2018).
range: This species is known from two nearby sites at the type locality in Cerro Las Antenas (between 1,780 and 1,945 m asl), on the eastern slope of Sierra de Perijá, Zulia state, Venezuela (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010; Rojas-Runjaic and Infante-Rivero 2018). However, it is possible that its range extends further to a 4,121 km2 area in Sierra de Perijá (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no records of use or trade for this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation actions in-place:
There are no conservation actions for this species. Its only known locality is in a non-protected area, but this species could also be present in the nearby Sierra de Perijá National Park, ca 6 km away from its type locality.

Conservation actions needed:
Cerro Las Antenas, the only known locality for this species, should be granted protection, until its presence is confirmed elsewhere.

Research needed:
Because this species is known from a single locality on unprotected land, but its geographic distribution could extend to Sierra de Perijá National Park, an under-explored protected area, further surveys are needed to determine its geographic distribution, population size and the protection status of this population. Also, habitat requirements need to be investigated and human activities associated with agricultural practices in neighbouring lowlands and with the operation of the antennas located where this species was found need to be monitored.

Listed as VU D2 in the Red List Book of the Venezuelan Fauna (Rojas-Runjaic and Señaris 2015).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its estimated extent of occurrence is about 7,015 km2, it is known from only five locations, and currently three of them are threatened by habitat conversion into crop plantations, and by other human activities associated with  service infrastructure development.
habitat: It occurs in pristine premontane and montane forests, including evergreen and cloud forests (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010; Rojas-Runjaic and Infante-Rivero 2018). It is also common in coffee plantations and secondary forest patches next to cocoyam (Xanthosoma sagittifolium) plantations, which suggest is is tolerant to some degree of habitat disturbance. It is a nocturnal terrestrial species that lives in the understory and near the forest floor. Males call in choruses during the night, hidden or exposed, from leaves and branches of shrubs up to 4 m above the ground (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010; Meza-Joya 2016). As in other Pristimantis, this species is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: Habitat loss and degradation are the major ongoing threats to this species. In three of the five known locations (including one within Sierra de Perijá National Park in Venezuela), habitats have been converted to coffee and cocoyam plantations, or impacted by transportation corridors, occasional fires or water abstraction.The increasing demand of cocoyam for commercial purposes during the last decades has accelerated deforestation in the vicinity of Cerro Las Antenas, the northernmost location of the species ((IUCN SSC ASG 2012; Rojas-Runjaic and Infante-Rivero 2018). The location in La Guajira department (Colombia) also has a relatively high degree of human disturbances, mainly associated with grazing.
population: Population size and trends have not been assessed for this species, but it is common in all of the five localities where it is found. Its population is not severely fragmented.
range: This species is known from five distant localities between 850–1,933 m asl in Sierra de Perijá; four are located on the eastern slope in Zulia, state, Venezuela, and one on the western slope, in Colombia, (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010; Meza-Joya 2016; Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2016). This species may occur more widely across Sierra de Perijá, in premontane and montane forests.
useTrade: There are no records of use or trade for this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
More than 71% of the extent of occurrence of this species is within Sierra de Perijá National Park in Venezuela (and likely also in part of Catatumbo Barí Colombia Natural National Park in Colombia).

Conservation Needed
Considering that some sectors of the Sierra de Perijá National Park are being altered by agricultural activities, the environmental protection of these areas must be reinforced in order to guarantee their protection and reduce the loss of habitat within their limits.

Research Needed
Since Sierra de Perijá is a relatively under explored area, systematic surveys are needed to determine its population size and trend, changes in its geographic distribution, its habitat requirements and its vulnerability to ongoing threats.

rationale: This stork is listed as Endangered because it has a very small, fragmented population which is very rapidly declining, owing to destruction of lowland forest through logging, dam construction and conversion to oil-palm plantations.
habitat: It occurs at low densities in large, undisturbed blocks of level lowland forest, particularly freshwater and peat-swamp forests, on the floodplains of large rivers. It also frequents disturbed, recently burned and logged areas, and occasionally areas subject to tidal movements, although these may constitute suboptimal habitats. It is generally solitary, but is occasionally found in small groups. Two eggs are usually laid and the chicks are able to fly after c.90 days.
threats: The main threats are forest loss and fragmentation as a result of logging and dam construction and conversion to oil-palm plantations (Kalimantan lost nearly 25% of its evergreen forest during 1985-1997, and Sumatra lost almost 30% of its 1985 cover), combined with associated increases in disturbance. The impact of the major fires of 1997-1998 on Sumatra and Borneo is still unclear, but they are likely to have been significant. The development of lowland rivers as major transport routes is presumably a considerable threat. Incidental hunting and trade are minor threats.
population: The population is estimated to number 150 individuals in Malaysia (Yeap Chin Aik in litt. 2002), and up to 250 individuals in Indonesia (M. Silvius in litt. 2002), totalling fewer than 500 individuals in total (Y. Noor Rusila in litt. 2002). The population size is likely to lie between 400-500 individuals, roughly equating to 260-330 mature individuals.
range: Ciconia stormi is known from extreme southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra (Indonesia), and the island of Borneo, where it occurs in Sabah and Sarawak (Malaysia), Brunei, and Kalimantan (Indonesia). It has been reduced to one tiny population and scattered individuals in Peninsular Malaysia, and was thought to be extinct in Thailand until an individual was camera trapped in the Klong Saeng-Khao Sok Forest Complex in April 2004 where a very small breeding population may remain (Cutter et al. 2007). An important breeding population comprising at least 43 individuals was identified in the Lower Kinabatangan Floodplain, Sabah in 1999-2000 (Abidin ben Ja'afar et al. 2001). The species was also recently recorded at Ulu Segama and photographed in Malua Forest Reserve, Sabah (A. J. Hearn in litt. 2008). The core of the remaining population is in Sumatra (including on Siberut [Verbelen 2010]), Kalimantan and Brunei, where it still appears to be widespread, but rare. Overall, the population is now estimated to number 260-330 mature individuals.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
It is legally protected in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. It has been recorded in numerous protected areas, including at least five (and one proposed) in Kalimantan, at least four (and a further four proposed) on Sumatra (including Way Kambas) and up to five (including Taman Negara, Lower Kinabatangan and Malua Forest Reserve [A. J. Hearn in litt. 2008]) in Malaysia. A small-scale nest protection scheme and awareness campaign is ongoing in West Kalimantan including compensation payments to poachers for nest protection, allowing at least four chicks to fledge between 2009-11 (Widmann et al. 2010, P. Widmann in litt. 2012).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Continue further surveys to determine its distribution, population and habitat requirements, particularly in Kalimantan (e.g. Cheyne et al. 2014). Establish further protected areas at sites supporting significant populations, including gazetting proposed reserves, particularly on Sumatra. Lobby for the cessation of logging in swamp-forests. Improve effectiveness of protection measures in protected areas in Indonesia.

rationale: The species has undergone a moderately rapid decline and therefore qualifies as as Near Threatened.
habitat: It breeds along forest edges and openings, semi-open forest, water edges and harvested forest where some structure has been retained. Prominent trees serve as singing and foraging posts, and both sexes are aggressively territorial (Altman and Sallabanks 2000).
threats: Habitat loss and alteration of forest management practices may limit breeding success (Altman 1997). However, numerous studies suggest that several types of harvested forest are beneficial to the species (possibly recreating preferred post-forest fire habitat mosaics) (Altman and Sallabanks 2000). Insect availability on the breeding grounds is affecting many flycatching species throughout North America, and especially in eastern Canada (G. Butcher in litt. 2016). This species has been reported to suffer mortality as a result of collisions with communications towers (Longcore et al. 2013). Unknown threats may be affecting the species on its wintering grounds.
population: Rich et al. (2004).
range: Contopus cooperi breeds across Canada (overlapping into eastern USA) and Alaska, and down the west coast of the USA as far as northern Mexico. There are also isolated populations in several states in the eastern USA (Altman and Sallabanks 2000). It winters primarily in Panama and the Andes Mountains, from north and west Venezuela south through Ecuador to south-east Peru and west Bolivia (Altman and Sallabanks 2000). Casual wintering also occurs in the Guianas, Trinidad, south Venezuela, Brazil and south Peru (Altman and Sallabanks 2000). Based on data from the Breeding Bird Survey the population has declined by 3.5% annually since 1980, equating to a 30% decline over a ten year period, but a 20.6% decline for the period 1993-2002. Given the apparent benefits to the species of some forest management practices in north America, populations may be being affected by loss or alteration of habitat in their wintering grounds.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
No species specific actions are known, but it is on the watch list as part of the State of North America's Birds (North American Bird Conservation Initiative 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Identify causes behind the declines. Develop and implement relevant actions once this first step has been completed.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence is less than 50 km<sup>2</sup>, its distribution is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This fossorial species has been recorded in mixed deciduous forest in the high elevations of Kolli Hills (Ganesh and Arumugarm 2016). The holotype was collected from beneath a small rock in mid-elevation dry evergreen forest (Aengals and Ganesh 2013).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss through conversion of forests to slash-and-burn agriculture (e.g. rice paddies, millet, tapioca and pineapple). This snake has been observed in coffee and cardamon plantations, but it is unclear if the species can persist in these habitats. In addition, there is heavy road traffic in this region and roadkill is considered a valid threat.
population: This is an uncommon species, with little information on the population trends.
range: This species is so far known only from its type locality in the Bodamalai Hills and the adjacent Kolli Hills, Eastern Ghats of Tamil Nadu, India (Aengals and Ganesh 2013, Ganesh and Arumugarm 2016). It occurs from around 900 to 1,370 m asl and represents the only Rhinophis sp. from the Eastern Ghats (Pyron et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The geographic range of this species does not include any protected areas. Protection of suitable habitat within the species restricted range is needed. Additional studies are needed into the natural history, especially population studies and monitoring for this species.

rationale: Although this species may have a small range, it is not believed to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (extent of occurrence <20,000 km2 combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). Despite the fact that the population trend appears to be decreasing, the rate of decline is unknown but not believed to be sufficiently rapid to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size may be small, but it is not believed to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). Therefore, the species is listed as Least Concern, but further information regarding the impact of trapping on this species may mean it warrants uplisting in the future.
habitat: It is resident in marshes and along streams within or at the edge of moist forest, and occasionally mangroves, favouring dense vegetation including tangled thickets of rattan and pandanus. Breeding may be related to rainfall and humidity, and negatively correlated with temperature (Ezhilarasi and Vijayan 2013).
threats: It is known to be under heavy trapping pressure, and may also be declining as a result of increasing habitat destruction and degradation through forest clearance for settlements, cultivation, road construction, and other infrastructural projects. Introduced predators are another potential threat.
population: The population is estimated to number 10,000-25,000 individuals in total, roughly equivalent to 6,700-17,000 mature individuals. However, there have been low encounter rates during surveys, and the population size could be lower (P. Davidar in litt.  2016); though these low encounter rates could be due to difficulties in locating the species, and it may be locally common in its preferred habitat (P. Davidar in litt. 2016).
range: Rallina canningi is endemic to the Andaman Islands, in the Bay of Bengal, India, where there are records from several islands in the Andamans (see Pande et al. 2007, eBird 2017), although it may be rare on smaller islands (P. Davidar in litt. 2016). Formerly considered very common based on high trapping rates, there were very few recent records until survey work in 2004 found it to be fairly common in suitable habitat (Ezhilarasi and Vijayan 2008). However, there have been low encounter rates during surveys, though this could be due to difficulties in locating the species, and it may be locally common in its preferred habitat (P. Davidar in litt. 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
It is known from several Protected Areas. The Department of Environment and Forests, Andaman & Nicobar Islands has initiated steps to conserve the endemic and threatened bird species of Andaman and Nicobar Islands and the Zoological Survey of India is monitoring the bird population of this archipelago (C. Sivaperuman in litt. 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Conduct surveys throughout its range to determine its current population size. Assess the extent and impact of habitat loss on populations. Quantify the impact of trapping on populations. Try to stop trapping if appropriate. Protect large areas of suitable habitat at key sites, in both strictly protected areas and community-led multiple use areas.

rationale: This species qualifies as Vulnerable because the rate of habitat loss at one of its two main sites in Tanzania appears to be high as its thorn-scrub habitat is being severely fragmented by encroaching cultivation and livestock farming, and there are indications that following an earlier expansion the range at the other main Tanzanian site may be undergoing a contraction; as the species is highly habitat-specific, its population is projected to decline rapidly in the near future.
habitat: In Tanzania the species is encountered almost exclusively in Acacia drepanolobium and A. seyal, 50% of individuals in the Wembere Steppe being found in the tallest, densest stands of A. drepanolobium, which accounted for less than 6% of the study area (Shaw et al. 2004, Shaw and Mungaya 2006). Even in extensive patches of A. drepanolobium the population density was low: c.3-7 pairs km-2 (Shaw and Mungaya 2006). Suitable habitat usually occurs in riverine areas, along seasonal watercourses and in seasonally inundated land. The species's distribution and abundance in Serengeti National Park has increased since the early 1990s, perhaps owing to vegetation changes associated with high grazing pressure, following an increase in wildebeest numbers in the 1970s (reducing the volume of combustible dry grass, thus limiting the damage caused by 'hot burns'), and reduced browsing pressure on Acacia seedlings, following a decline in the elephant population since the 1980s (Shaw 2007). The species forages in small family parties, with juveniles accounting for 18% of birds encountered in the Wembere Steppe in July (Shaw and Mungaya 2006). It occasionally forages in mixed-species flocks (D. C. Moyer in litt. 1999), searching for food mainly at a height of 1.5-2.5 m in A. drepanolobium trees over 2 m high (Shaw et al. 2004, Shaw and Mungaya 2006). It forages for invertebrate prey by gleaning and sally-gleaning from pseudo-galls, spines and leaves (Shaw et al. 2004, Shaw and Mungaya 2006). Its feeding and breeding ecology are largely unknown. So far it has been observed within an altitudinal range of 1,050-1,580 m (P. Shaw in litt. 2007).
threats: In Tanzania, it is at risk from habitat loss linked to an expanding human population, and because much of its restricted range lies outside protected areas. The area between the Serengeti ecosystem and the Wembere Steppe is now under great pressure from pastoralists and farmers, and is thought to have retained little suitable habitat, inhibiting exchange between the two areas. In the Wembere Steppe, A. drepanolobium is cleared for cultivation, cut and pruned for firewood and hedging material, browsed by goats and trampled by cattle, all of which limits regeneration, as does incidental burning from grass fires set to improve grazing quality (Shaw et al. 2004). These pressures are predicted to intensify as human and livestock populations increase (Shaw et al. 2004). The human population in districts encompassing the Wembere Steppe increased by 2.2-3.7% per year between 1978 and 2002, and in Igunga District, where bulk of the species's Wembere population resides, the human population increased by 4.3% per year between 1988 and 2002 (Shaw et al. 2004). Increasing cultivation and livestock farming may also be threatening the species in Uganda (H. J. Rainey verbally 1999). In 1996, it was noted that large amounts of cultivation and wood-cutting were threatening to reduce potential habitat for the species in the Mt Kadam region, and evidence of the over-grazing of trees and bushes was observed at Napianyenya (Rainey undated). Although the species appears to have benefited from changes in ungulate populations in the Serengeti, which have influenced burning intensity and hence tree regeneration, its range now appears to be declining following a recent reduction in the density and annual survival of A. drepanolobium in the northern Serengeti (Shaw 2009). Infrastructure development (oil pipeline from Uganda to the coast through Tanzania, and other major transport links such as roads in northern Tanzania) in the region may also pose a threat, and should be reviewed to understand how much of a threat it may pose to this species (H. Rainey in litt. 2016).
population: Surveys of the Wembere Steppe and Serengeti ecosystem in Tanzania suggest a total population in the range 300-1,500 birds (P. Shaw in litt. 2007). No estimates are available for the Ugandan population. The preliminary estimate of 10,000-19,999 individuals is retained pending further information. This equates to 6,667-13,333 mature individuals, rounded here to 6,000-15,000 mature individuals.
range: Apalis karamojae occurs mainly in north-east Uganda and northern Tanzania. An individual was recorded in southern Kenya in August 2004, north of the Masai Mara, between Narok and Sekenani (Boy 2004, Shaw 2007), 105 km north-east of the nearest known Tanzanian location. Up to two pairs have since been recorded several times at the same site (P. Shaw in litt. 2005, 2006, 2007, Shaw 2007). In Uganda, the nominate subspecies (Stuart and Collar 1986) is known from: Kanatorok (only one bird was seen during survey work in 1998 [Rossouw 2001]), Mt Moroto, Mt Kamalinga (Mt Napak), and Mt Kadam (Urban et al. 1997). In 2015 there was a sighting of one bird c.25km north of Mbale (the habitat is quite extensive and so they may be more common than this single sighting [D. Pomeroy in litt. to P. Shaw 2016]). It could not be found at a further known site, Napianyenya, in August 1996 (H. J. Rainey verbally 1999, Rainey undated). During the 1960s the subspecies stronachi (Stuart and Collar 1986) was known from at least four sites in Tanzania, all of them in, or near to, the Wembere Steppe: at Ngongoro, Itumba, Ndala, and between Nzega and Igunga. A survey in 2003 showed that the species's range in and adjacent to the Wembere Steppe was less extensive than had been assumed, with records spanning an area of 102 km north-south by 53 km east-west (Shaw and Mungaya 2006). Since 1993 (and possibly as early as 1983) the species has also been recorded in the Serengeti ecosystem, initially near to Ndutu (Urban et al. 1997), Moru Kopjes and the edge of Maswa Game Reserve (D. C. Moyer in litt. 1999). Since 2000 the species became increasingly widespread in the Western Corridor of Serengeti National Park, which now appears to be its main Tanzanian stronghold (Shaw 2007). Records from the Serengeti during 1993-2007 spanned 123 km north-south by 123 km east-west (Shaw 2007), but there are indications that the range there may now have started to decline following recent reductions in the density and survival of its preferred Acacia woodland in the northern Serengeti (Shaw 2009). There is also a single record from Tarangire National Park (P. Shaw in litt. 2007).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
Serengeti National Park now appears to hold the bulk of the species's Tanzanian population (Shaw 2007). The species has also been recorded from Maswa Game Reserve (D. C. Moyer in litt. 1999) and Tarangire National Park (P. Shaw in litt. 2007). In Uganda it occurs in Kidepo National Park. Aside from surveys carried out in Tanzania in 2003 (Shaw et al. 2004) and 2005-2006 (Shaw 2007), there have been no conservation or research programmes specifically targeting this species or its habitat. Surveys in Uganda are difficult because of security problems in the north-east.

Conservation Actions Proposed
When feasible, determine its status in Uganda, initially by surveying sites occupied in the past (P. Shaw in litt. 2007). In Serengeti National Park maintain conditions likely to promote the continued expansion of Acacia woodland, i.e. high grazing pressure and controlled burning, which limits the frequency of damaging 'hot burns', and low browsing pressure on Acacia seedlings (Shaw 2007). Assess the population size and distribution in Maswa and Grumeti Game Reserves (Shaw 2007). Determine whether suitable habitat remains within the area separating the Wembere Steppe from the Serengeti ecosystem (particularly the Yaeda Valley), providing a potential habitat corridor linking the two apalis populations (P. Shaw in litt. 2007). Assess the rate and pattern of change in scrub cover bordering the Wembere Steppe (Shaw et al. 2004). Promote the retention and regeneration of A. drepanolobium cover in the Wembere Steppe, through advocacy and/or the provision of incentives to subsistence farmers (Shaw et al. 2004). In Kenya conduct a survey in the Masai Mara National Reserve and adjoining group ranches (P. Shaw in litt. 2007). Identify ecological factors limiting the species's range, which is much less extensive than that of its main habitat (P. Shaw in litt. 2007). Investigate to what extent infrastructure development in this region may be impacting upon this species (H. Rainey in litt. 2016).

rationale: This species has suffered rapid population reductions across most of its range owing to the loss, degradation and fragmentation of its habitat, as well as hunting. Some populations in its Iberian stronghold have been suggested to have stabilised and possibly increased, although there is now some evidence for at least local declines in some areas in this region. Additionally, hunting in Central and East Asia results in high rates of adult mortality, and land-use changes in eastern Europe, Russia, Central Asia and Morocco may have a significant impact on this species's population and the extent of its remaining habitat, such that it is likely to decline at a rapid rate over the next three generations. It therefore qualifies as Vulnerable. Should research show the species to be declining at a more moderate rate, it would warrant downlisting to a lower category of threat.
habitat: Originally a species of the Eurasian steppe, this species has acclimated to agricultural landscapes (M. Kessler in litt. 2016). It occurs in open, flat or somewhat rolling landscapes, usually with a mixture of crops (cereals, vineyards, fodder plants, in some countries also with steppic grassland [J. C. Alonso in litt. 2012]). The eastern subspecies inhabits both open steppe and forest steppe, including small forest openings (M. Kessler in litt. 2016). Areas with little or no disturbance and abundant supply of insects are required for successful breeding (Y. Andryushchenko in litt. 1999). Nest sites are selected in grassland, fallow or cereal fields (Rocha et al. 2013) (primarily alfalfa in Central Europe and wheat in Russia, Mongolia and Kazakhstan [M. Kessler in litt. 2016]) in areas of low patch-type diversity, far from human infrastructure and with good horizontal visibility (Magaña et al. 2010). The eastern subspecies nests in agricultural mosaics, open steppe, and adjacent to forest edge (Kessler 2015). It exhibits highly variable migratory behaviour across populations, including obligate winter migrants (Asia, Russia), facultative migrants (central European populations) and partial winter and summer migrants with differential migratory pattern by sex (Iberian populations) (Morales et al. 2000, Alonso et al. 2000, 2001, Palacín et al. 2009, 2011).
threats: Key threats are increased habitat degradation, fragmentation and loss due to agricultural intensification, land-use changes and infrastructure development which has the potential to increase following land privatisation in eastern Europe (S.
